Humanities Grad Students
Profs. To Increase 70%
In $4.5 Million Program
A seventy per cent increase in
the number of Hopkins' graduate
humanities students and professors is included in the $4.5 million 10-year humanities development program, announced in the
News-Letter December 11, 1964.
A Postdoctoral Center for Humanistic Study and a concentrated program of graduate study
to reduce the time spent earning
the Ph.D. have also been planned.
Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower said
that the program was designed
to achieve two primary objectives. Through the work of the
Postdoctoral Center for Humanistic Study, the University is
seeking to raise standards of
humanistic education and scholarship in the United States.
Through its increased graduate
enrollment and the concentrated
Ph.D. program, Hopkins is seeking to increase the supply of
qualified scholars to teach in
United States colleges and universities.
With the support of the University's Trustees the humanities
program has received top priority
as a goal in the Johns Hopkins
development campaign, Dr. Eisenhower said. The University is

The Machine has again improved the procedures of life at
the Homewood, this time as a
means of recording and reporting grades. The computerized
record system, which has replaced
the
old
typewritten
transcripts, will enable the registrar's office to have reports of
first term grades in the hands of
students before advising and registration for the second semester.
Grade reports will be issued
Through campus mail on Monday, February 1, so that students
will for the first time be able
to plan for the future with
knowledge of their performance
in the recent past. Any grades
missing from a report will be due
to the failure of some faculty
member to file grade sheets with
the Registrar by noon on Saturday.
All academic records of freshmen and sophomores have already been placed on the computer system. Though juniors
and seniors remain on the old
system, they too will receive the
new early grade reports from the
Registrar's computer.

schedule of courses to be offered
next term will be available at
her office next Friday, January
15. Courses to be given for the
first time, and therefore not listed in the catalog include Digital

Dissidents in Residence
No one ever intimated that the lack of campus
agitation and restlessness gave this college an appearance of a finishing school—but a few have announced
that there is no intellectual life without risks, and that
the core of scholarship is inquiry, and the core of
inquiry is subversion.
Admittedly, there is even a risk in the announcing
of it. The administrators must keep the record books
straight, of who is a bad boy and who is good; and whoeNer's balance in the book is unfavorable is taken to task.
But within a network of checks and restrictions
which we can count on, we can and should test the
balance and maybe also our leeway, not wholly for the
sake of negation of customary practices but in a game
of questioning, the prize for which is living.
The best university is not the one well-groomed,
but the one where some wild hairs challenge the direction of the others and a customary habit is permitted
an unaccustomed turn.
There must be the bohemians. Not only because
they are marginal people can they provide insights into
the community, but as an establishment, they are an
institution for disestablishment. They are the advocates
of negation, the dissidents in residence.
There must he a student newspaper. And the best
of these is one untrammeled by university and administration mottoes. After doling out notices and praises
where such is due, the organ might well handle less official business: a circus for sportive inquiry anti a
forum for subtle or not SO subtle acrobatics in all sorts
of expression and high-wire observation.
We ought never, however, wish for the extreme of
such subversion: that is, the opposite of all. It would
he intriguing to cultivate the opposite of education,
ignorance, or to play the opposite of football here, which
is not to play football, or even wish the same effect on
illU: that is, no Johns Hopkins University ... but
it is a futile scheme.
What shall we call this mode?
We call this proposed mode the antithetical syndrome, ostensibly extinct in these parts, but liberally
available to anyone.

Dissidents in Residence
No one ever intimated that the lack of campus
agitation and restlessness gave this college an appearance of a finishing school—but a few have announced
that there is no intellectual life without risks, and that
the core of scholarship is inquiry, and the core of
inquiry is subversion.
Admittedly, there is even a risk in the announcing
of it. The administrators must keep the record books
straight, of who is a bad boy and who is good; and whoeNer's balance in the book is unfavorable is taken to task.
But within a network of checks and restrictions
which we can count on, we can and should test the
balance and maybe also our leeway, not wholly for the
sake of negation of customary practices but in a game
of questioning, the prize for which is living.
The best university is not the one well-groomed,
but the one where some wild hairs challenge the direction of the others and a customary habit is permitted
an unaccustomed turn.
There must be the bohemians. Not only because
they are marginal people can they provide insights into
the community, but as an establishment, they are an
institution for disestablishment. They are the advocates
of negation, the dissidents in residence.
There must he a student newspaper. And the best
of these is one untrammeled by university and administration mottoes. After doling out notices and praises
where such is due, the organ might well handle less official business: a circus for sportive inquiry anti a
forum for subtle or not SO subtle acrobatics in all sorts
of expression and high-wire observation.
We ought never, however, wish for the extreme of
such subversion: that is, the opposite of all. It would
he intriguing to cultivate the opposite of education,
ignorance, or to play the opposite of football here, which
is not to play football, or even wish the same effect on
illU: that is, no Johns Hopkins University ... but
it is a futile scheme.
What shall we call this mode?
We call this proposed mode the antithetical syndrome, ostensibly extinct in these parts, but liberally
available to anyone.
